page.title: 14 Architecture of Much Hadham
page.content: At the North end of the village the houses are practically continuous and the natural curve of the road emphasizes the row of different sized buildings abutting straight onto the pavements with no front gardens. These houses date mostly from the 16th and 17th centuries. They are of timber and plaster construction with steep pitched roofs. Some have Georgian fronts, some are half timbered and there are prominent gables, tall chimneys and pretty windows and porches. Most of these buildings were small shops.This year marked the end of Betty Saunders' little shop, much loved by the children especially. Together with these are a number of medium sized country houses of some architectural interest.Most of these houses are ofthe Georgian period but are built on the sites of older ones.
